New Perspectives on the Polyak Stepsize:
Surrogate Functions and Negative Results

Francesco Orabona
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST)
Thuwal, 23955-6900, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
francesco@orabona.com â€ƒâ€ƒ Ryan Dâ€™Orazio
Mila QuÃ©bec AI Institute, UniversitÃ© de MontrÃ©al
MontrÃ©al, QC, Canada
ryan.dorazio@mila.quebec
Abstract

The Polyak stepsize has been proven to be a fundamental stepsize in convex optimization, giving near optimal gradient descent rates across a wide range of assumptions. The universality of the Polyak stepsize has also inspired many stochastic variants, with theoretical guarantees and strong empirical performance. Despite the many theoretical results, our understanding of the convergence properties and shortcomings of the Polyak stepsize or its variants is both incomplete and fractured across different analyses. We propose a new, unified, and simple perspective for the Polyak stepsize and its variants as gradient descent on a surrogate loss. We show that each variant is equivalent to minimize a surrogate function with stepsizes that adapt to a guaranteed local curvature. Our general surrogate loss perspective is then used to provide a unified analysis of existing variants across different assumptions. Moreover, we show a number of negative results proving that the non-convergence results in some of the upper bounds is indeed real.

1 Introduction

The iterative optimization of complex functions forms a cornerstone of modern machine learning, scientific computing, and engineering. Among the most foundational first-order methods is gradient descent, which iteratively refines a solution by moving in the direction opposite to the functionâ€™s gradient. A critical aspect of gradient descent is the selection of an appropriate stepsize (or learning rate), as it dictates both the speed of convergence and the stability of the algorithm. The wrong choice of the stepsizes can lead to slow convergence or, conversely, to divergence, making the tuning process a significant practical hurdle.

In this landscape of stepsize selection strategies, the Polyak stepsize, proposed by Polyak (1969) stands out for its theoretical elegance and convergence properties. Starting from an arbitrary ğ’™1âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ’™1superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{x}_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the Polyak stepsize is defined as

ğ’™t+1=ğ’™tâˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’fâ‹†â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2â¢ğ’ˆt,subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘“â‹†superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\frac{f(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-f^{\star}}% {\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}\boldsymbol{g}_{t},bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1)

where ğŸâ‰ ğ’ˆtâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™t)0subscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{0}\neq\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})bold_0 â‰  bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and fâ‹†=minğ’™â¡fâ¢(ğ’™)superscriptğ‘“â‹†subscriptğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™f^{\star}=\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x})italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). If ğ’ˆt=ğŸsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡0\boldsymbol{g}_{t}=\boldsymbol{0}bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0, then ğ’™t+1=ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This update rule can achieve linear convergence for strongly convex and smooth functions, ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) rate for convex smooth functions, and ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T})caligraphic_O ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG ) rate for non-smooth convex ones. This is particularly interesting because all of these rates are achieved with a unique stepsize and without knowledge of smoothness or curvature constants. In other words, this update rule is adaptive to the geometry of the functions to optimize.

Recently, the Polyak stepsize has seen a resurgence in the machine learning literature, with a plethora of variants. However, despite the big number of papers on this topic, one essential research question seems still to be missing: What makes the Polyak stepsize adaptive and when can it fail?

Contributions. This paper aims to provide a novel framework to understand the Polyak stepsize, providing a clear geometric explanation of its adaptivity. In particular, we show that the adaptivity is due to a simple but powerful observation: The Polyak stepsize minimizes a surrogate objective function that is always locally smooth. As for standard smooth functions, we will show that the knowledge of the local smoothness constant is enough to obtain the correct rates. In addition, the local smoothness will depend only on the gradient itself, removing the need to estimate it. Furthermore, we show that minimal curvature of the surrogate is inherited from the original function as well. We also use this framework to extend its core idea to a family of algorithms. Then, we will show a number of negative results when fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is not known and for its use in the stochastic case. These negative results complete our understanding by showing that some non-vanishing terms in existing upper bounds are necessary.

2 Related Work

In the pionnering work of Â Ermolâ€™ev (1966) stepsizes of the form Î·tâˆ1/â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2proportional-tosubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2\eta_{t}\propto\nicefrac{{1}}{{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ / start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG were proposed for non-smooth optimization. Despite the many convergence guarantees enabled by Â Ermolâ€™ev (1966)â€™s framework, in Â Polyak (1969) it is noted that linear convergence is not possible with such stepsizes. As an alternative, Polyak suggests the stepsizeÂ (1), which is shown to converge at favourable rates with non-smooth convex functions, and strongly convex and smooth functions. In fact, contrary to common belief, Polyak (1969) was the first to show linear convergence with a rate comparable to gradient descent in the smooth and strongly convex case. Furthermore, the case where fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is estimated was also studied, showing convergence to a level set if fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is overestimated, and convergence to a neighboorhood if it is underestimated. The Polyak stepsize has since been extended and studied across several applications and domains.

Non-smooth convex. In non-smooth convex optimization, several schemes have been developed to estimate fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the flyÂ (BrÃ¤nnlund, 1993; Bertsekas, 1999; Goffin and Kiwiel, 1999; Sherali etÂ al., 2000; Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001; Kiwiel, 2004). In the finite-sum case with interpolation,Â (1) and variants have been studied as an incremental subgradient methodÂ (Nedic and Bertsekas, 2001; Kiwiel, 2004).

Non-expansive operators. In the context of non-expansive operators, the updateÂ (1) has also been studied as a special case of the subgradient projectorÂ (Bauschke and Combettes, 2017; Cegielski, 2012; Combettes, 2009). Where it can be shown that subgradient descent with Î·t=(fâ¢(x)âˆ’c)+/â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2\eta_{t}=\nicefrac{{(f(x)-c)_{+}}}{{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = / start_ARG ( italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_c ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is a quasi-firmly non-expansive operator111An operator Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is quasi-firmly non-expansive if for all fixed points ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, â€–Tâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2â‰¤â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’â€–Tâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2superscriptnormğ‘‡ğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptnormğ‘‡ğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}âˆ¥ italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that a quasi-firmly non-expansive operators are also referred to as cutters. if fğ‘“fitalic_f is convex and câ‰¥fâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ‘“â‹†c\geq f^{\star}italic_c â‰¥ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ğ’™â†’ğ’™â‹†â†’ğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}\to\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x â†’ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if fğ‘“fitalic_f is continuousÂ (Bauschke and Combettes, 2017). Moreover, in the finite-sum setting, interpolation can also be viewed as iterating different quasi-firmly non-expansive operators with a common fixed point. For example, applying a subgradient projector sequentially (i.e., cycling through the different component functions) in a way such that each function eventually gets visited guarantees that ğ’™tâ†’{fâ¢(ğ’š)â‰¤c}â†’subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\to\{f(\boldsymbol{y})\leq c\}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ { italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) â‰¤ italic_c }Â (Cegielski, 2012, Example 5.9.7). For a survey on this topic seeÂ Censor (1984).

Deterministic. In modern optimization, (1) has been shown to achieve similar rates to gradient descent in various common assumptions (e.g., Lipschitz, smoothness and strong convexity)Â (Hazan and Kakade, 2019), and more recently with other assumptions such as weakly convex functionsÂ (Davis etÂ al., 2018), (L0,L1)subscriptğ¿0subscriptğ¿1(L_{0},L_{1})( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-smooth functionsÂ (Takezawa etÂ al., 2024; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2025), and directional smoothnessÂ (Mishkin etÂ al., 2024).

Stochastic. The Polyak stepsize has also been extended to the stochastic case with emphasis on applications to machine learningÂ (Rolinek and Martius, 2018; Berrada etÂ al., 2020; Loizou etÂ al., 2021; Prazeres and Oberman, 2021). The ALI-G methodÂ (Berrada etÂ al., 2020) and SPSmaxÂ (Loizou etÂ al., 2021) use stochastic estimates via the sampled function fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒf(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) and its gradient âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒ\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) to perform a Polyak-like stepsize. SPSmaxÂ in addition uses infxfâ¢(x,ğƒ)subscriptinfimumğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğƒ\inf_{x}f(x,\boldsymbol{\xi})roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) as an estimate to fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and is shown to converge at fast rates without a neighbourhood under interpolation. Folowing SPSmaxÂ many variants have been proposed for SGD: StoPSÂ (HorvÃ¡th etÂ al., 2022), DECSPS and SPSâ„“maxsuperscriptsubscriptabsentâ„“{}_{\max}^{\ell}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ (Orvieto etÂ al., 2022), SPS+subscriptSPS\texttt{SPS}_{+}SPS start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPTÂ (Garrigos etÂ al., 2023). Beyond SGD, other extensions include: mirror descentÂ (Dâ€™Orazio etÂ al., 2023), with preconditioningÂ (Abdukhakimov etÂ al., 2024), with line-searchÂ (Jiang and Stich, 2023), and with momentumÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2023; Schaipp etÂ al., 2024; Oikonomou and Loizou, 2025).

Neighbourhood of Convergence. For SPSmax, Loizou etÂ al. (2021) proved that the suboptimality gap is only guaranteed to shrink up to a factor that depends on the loss themselves. As we will explain in SectionÂ 5.1, this is equivalent to the guarantees in online learning where the regret is proportional to the cumulative loss of the competitor, typically denoted by Lâ‹†superscriptğ¿â‹†L^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, these kind of guarantees are usually called in online learning Lâ‹†superscriptğ¿â‹†L^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT boundsÂ (see, e.g., Orabona, 2019, Section 4.2).

Surprisingly enough, despite the adaptivity of the Polyak stepsize across various assumptions without modification, in previous literature there is no clear explanation why this is the case.

3 Definitions and Notation

We will use the following notation and definitions. All the norms in this paper are L2 norms and they will denoted by âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥. For a function f:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R, we define a subgradient of fğ‘“fitalic_f in ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as a vector ğ’ˆâˆˆâ„dğ’ˆsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{g}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_g âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that satisfies fâ¢(ğ’š)â‰¥fâ¢(ğ’™)+âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™âŸ©,âˆ€ğ’šâˆˆâ„dformulae-sequenceğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“ğ’™ğ’ˆğ’šğ’™for-allğ’šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘f(\boldsymbol{y})\geq f(\boldsymbol{x})+\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-% \boldsymbol{x}\rangle,\ \forall\boldsymbol{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) â‰¥ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) + âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x âŸ© , âˆ€ bold_italic_y âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We denote the set of subgradients of fğ‘“fitalic_f in ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x by âˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™)ğ‘“ğ’™\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). For a differentiable function we have that âˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™)={âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’™)}ğ‘“ğ’™âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})=\{\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})\}âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) = { âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) }. A function f:Vâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’ğ‘‰â„f:V\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : italic_V â†’ blackboard_R, differentiable in an open set containing Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, is Lğ¿Litalic_L-smooth w.r.t. âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\|âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ if fâ¢(ğ’š)â‰¤fâ¢(ğ’™)+âŸ¨âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’™),ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™âŸ©+L2â¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“ğ’™âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™ğ’šğ’™ğ¿2superscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2f(\boldsymbol{y})\leq f(\boldsymbol{x})+\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}),% \boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y% }\|^{2}italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) â‰¤ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) + âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x âŸ© + divide start_ARG italic_L end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_y âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all ğ’™,ğ’šâˆˆVğ’™ğ’šğ‘‰\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in Vbold_italic_x , bold_italic_y âˆˆ italic_V.

Definition 1.

We say that a function fğ‘“fitalic_f has a sğ‘ sitalic_s-sharp minimum in ğ±â‹†superscriptğ±â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¥sâ¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–.ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ‘ normğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\geq s\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{% x}^{\star}\|~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_s âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Note that fğ‘“fitalic_f has a sharp minimum then it is not differentiable at ğ’™âˆ—superscriptğ’™âˆ—\boldsymbol{x}^{\ast}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ (Polyak, 1987) and if the function is also convex and GğºGitalic_G-Lipschitz we immediately have Gâ‰¥sğºğ‘ G\geq sitalic_G â‰¥ italic_s.

Definition 2.

We say that a function f:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R is Lğ¿Litalic_L-self-bounded if

â€–ğ’ˆâ€–2â‰¤2â¢Lâ¢(fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’infğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™)),âˆ€ğ’™âˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™).formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormğ’ˆ22ğ¿ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptinfimumğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™for-allğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}\leq 2L(f(\boldsymbol{x})-\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})),\ \forall\boldsymbol{x}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})~{}.âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 2 italic_L ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) ) , âˆ€ bold_italic_x âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) .

It is known that Lğ¿Litalic_L-smooth functions are Lğ¿Litalic_L-self-boundedÂ (see, e.g., LemmaÂ 4 in Li and Orabona, 2019), but this definition is strictly weaker because it does not assume differentiability.

4 Polyak Stepsize is Gradient Descent on a Surrogate Function

Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be convex and ğ’™â‹†âˆˆargminğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™)superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptargminğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Consider the following function:

Ï•â¢(ğ’™)=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))2.italic-Ï•ğ’™12superscriptğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†2\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}\left(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star})\right)^{2}~{}.italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (2)

Instead of viewing the Polyak stepsize (1) with respect to fğ‘“fitalic_f we propose to view it equivalently as a subgradient method with respect to Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•. By the chain rule of subgradients (Bauschke and Combettes, 2017)[Corollary 16.72], subgradient descent with the Polyak stepsize (1) is equivalent to subgradient descent on Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• with stepsize Î·t=1â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This perspective may seem superfluous, howerever, we will show that 1â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–21superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is strongly related to a certain notion of local curvature of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, local star upper curvature.

Definition 3 (Local star upper curvature (LSUC)).

We say that a function fğ‘“fitalic_f with minimizer ğ±â‹†superscriptğ±â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has Î»ğ²subscriptğœ†ğ²\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-local star upper curvature (LSUC) around ğ²ğ²\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y if for all ğ²ğ²\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y there exists Î»ğ²>0subscriptğœ†ğ²0\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}>0italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 such that

fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’š,ğ’™â‹†âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¥12â¢Î»ğ’šâ¢â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–22,âˆ€ğ’ˆğ’šâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’š).formulae-sequenceğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ‘“ğ’šsubscriptğ’ˆğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†ğ’š12subscriptğœ†ğ’šsubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š22for-allsubscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ‘“ğ’šf(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol% {y}},\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2\lambda_{% \boldsymbol{y}}}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}_{2},\ \forall% \boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_y âŸ© â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ€ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) .

Note that the definition implies the convexity of fğ‘“fitalic_f since we assume the existence of a subgradient.222If ğ’ˆtsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡\boldsymbol{g}_{t}bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not a subgradient but a directional derivative then fğ‘“fitalic_f would be guaranteed to be star-convexÂ (Joulani etÂ al., 2020). It is also immediate to show that convex Lğ¿Litalic_L-smooth functions are also Lğ¿Litalic_L-LSUC. Indeed, for convex Lğ¿Litalic_L-smooth functions we have thatÂ (Nesterov, 2004, Theorem 2.1.5)

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’âŸ¨âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¥12â¢Lâ¢â€–âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ¢(ğ’š)â€–2,âˆ€ğ’™,ğ’šâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“ğ’šâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’šğ’™ğ’š12ğ¿superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’š2for-allğ’™ğ’šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y}),% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2L}\|\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x})% -\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y})\|^{2},\ \forall\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in% \mathbb{R}^{d}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_y âŸ© â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - âˆ‡ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ bold_italic_x , bold_italic_y âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

So, it is enough to set ğ’™=ğ’™â‹†ğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain the above definition. However, the inclusion is strict, because there exist functions that are not smooth and still satisfy the above definition. For example, one can easily verify that fâ¢(x)=|x+2|+x22ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¥22f(x)=|x+2|+\frac{x^{2}}{2}italic_f ( italic_x ) = | italic_x + 2 | + divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG is Lâ¢Sâ¢Uâ¢Cğ¿ğ‘†ğ‘ˆğ¶LSUCitalic_L italic_S italic_U italic_C but not differentiable, so not smooth.

Finally, if the star-upper-curvature holds globally, i.e., there exists 0<Î»<Î»ğ’š0ğœ†subscriptğœ†ğ’š0<\lambda<\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}0 < italic_Î» < italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all ğ’šğ’š\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y, then we can show that this condition is equivalent to the upper quadratic growth condition in Guille-Escuret etÂ al. (2021). This observation was first made by Goujaud etÂ al. (2022, Theorem 2.6), we include the precise statement and proof in the AppendixÂ B.

The key observation in the next Theorem is that Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is always locally star upper curved, regardless of the curvature (or lack of it) of the function fğ‘“fitalic_f. Moreover, it will inherit additional curvature from fğ‘“fitalic_f. The proof can be found in AppendixÂ A.

Theorem 1 (Curvature of the Polyak surrogate).

Let fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) be convex and define ğ±â‹†âˆˆargminğ±fâ¢(ğ±)superscriptğ±â‹†subscriptargminğ±ğ‘“ğ±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Define Ï•â¢(ğ±)=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ±â‹†))2italic-Ï•ğ±12superscriptğ‘“ğ±ğ‘“superscriptğ±â‹†2\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^% {2}italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have

  • â€¢

    Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š2\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-LSUC around any ğ’šğ’š\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y for any ğ’ˆğ’šâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’š)subscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ‘“ğ’š\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ).

  • â€¢

    If fğ‘“fitalic_f is sğ‘ sitalic_s-sharp, then Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• has s2superscriptğ‘ 2s^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-quadratic growth.

  • â€¢

    If fğ‘“fitalic_f has Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-quadratic growth and Lğ¿Litalic_L-self bounded, then Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• satisfies a local quadratic growth:

    Ï•â¢(ğ’™)â‰¥12â¢Î¼â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â¢Lâ¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2,âˆ€ğ’ˆâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™).formulae-sequenceitalic-Ï•ğ’™12ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’ˆ22ğ¿superscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2for-allğ’ˆğ‘“ğ’™\phi(\boldsymbol{x})\geq\frac{1}{2}\frac{\mu\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}{2L}\|% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2},\ \forall\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f% (\boldsymbol{x})~{}.italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) .

This theorem tells us that, regardless of the curvature of fğ‘“fitalic_f, we can always construct the function Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• that is locally curved. It is well-known that for Lğ¿Litalic_L-smooth functions one can use the stepsize Î·=1Lğœ‚1ğ¿\eta=\frac{1}{L}italic_Î· = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG and achieve a rate between ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) and a linear one, depending on the presence of strong convexity. Here, we show a similar result: GD can use stepsizes that depend on the local star upper curvature in all cases. Note however, unlike GD with a constant stepsize and smoothness, we do not have a descent lemma with Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•. Indeed this is not possible as it would guarantee a ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ) rate for the last iterate which was shown to be impossible byÂ Goujaud etÂ al. (2022) for Qâ¢G+(L)ğ‘„ğºğ¿QG+(L)italic_Q italic_G + ( italic_L ) functions (i.e., L-LUSC functions).

Lemma 1.

Let Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• convex and define ğ±â‹†âˆˆargminğ±Ï•â¢(ğ±)superscriptğ±â‹†subscriptargminğ±italic-Ï•ğ±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \phi(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ). Assume fğ‘“fitalic_f to be Î»ğ±subscriptğœ†ğ±\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-LSUC around any point ğ±ğ±\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x. Then, using GD with stepsizes Î·t=1Î»ğ±tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1subscriptğœ†subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}}}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG guarantees

Î·tâ¢(Ï•â¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’Ï•â¢(ğ’™â‹†))â‰¤12â¢â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’12â¢â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2.subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡italic-Ï•superscriptğ’™â‹†12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†212superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†2\eta_{t}\left(\phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\right)\leq% \frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}~{}.italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Summing this inequality over time, we also have

Ï•â¢(ğ’™Â¯T)â¢âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ‰¤âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ¢Ï•â¢(ğ’™t)â‰¤â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–22,italic-Ï•subscriptÂ¯ğ’™ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†22\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}% \phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\leq\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}% \|^{2}}{2},italic_Ï• ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , (4)

where ğ±Â¯T=1âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ¢ğ±tsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T}=\frac{1}{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}}\boldsymbol{x}_{t}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ±Â¯T=argminğ±âˆˆ{ğ±1,â€¦,ğ±T}Ï•â¢(ğ±)subscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘‡subscriptargminğ±subscriptğ±1â€¦subscriptğ±ğ‘‡italic-Ï•ğ±\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}\in\{% \boldsymbol{x}_{1},\dots,\boldsymbol{x}_{T}\}}\ \phi(\boldsymbol{x})overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x âˆˆ { bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ).

Proof.

From the classic one-step analysis of GDÂ (see, e.g., Orabona, 2019), we have

Î·tâ¢âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’™t,ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©=12â¢â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’12â¢â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2+Î·t22â¢â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2.subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†212superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡22superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2\displaystyle\eta_{t}\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}},\boldsymbol{x}% _{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle=\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol% {x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{% 2}+\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}}{2}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}~{}.italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Now, we use the fact that Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is LSUC and the definition of Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we obtain the stated bound. Summing from t=1ğ‘¡1t=1italic_t = 1 to Tğ‘‡Titalic_T and discarding the negative term on the right hand side concludes the proof. âˆ

The above discussion can be summarized in the following theorem.

Theorem 2.

The Polyak stepsize in (1) is equivalent to subgradient descent on the function Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• in (2), when using stepsizes Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal to the inverse of the local-star-upper curvature of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• in ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This theorem and LemmaÂ 1 do not give us a rate, however we can immediately observe that if âˆ‘tÎ·t=+âˆsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\sum_{t}\eta_{t}=+\inftyâˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = + âˆ we also have Ï•â¢(ğ’™t)â†’0â†’italic-Ï•subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡0\phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\to 0italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â†’ 0, that is, the last iterate will converge.

To obtain known rates for the Polyak stepsize, we can use additional assumptions on fğ‘“fitalic_f. However, we want to stress that, differently from prior results, we explicitly get a convergence rate for the surrogate function Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•, the function actually minimized by (1). The rates on the original function fğ‘“fitalic_f are immediate by just taking the square root.

If fğ‘“fitalic_f is GğºGitalic_G-Lipschitz, then âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ‰¥T/G2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘‡superscriptğº2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}\geq T/G^{2}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_T / italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence, the final rate is Ï•â¢(ğ’™Â¯T)â‰¤G22â¢Tâ¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2italic-Ï•subscriptÂ¯ğ’™ğ‘‡superscriptğº22ğ‘‡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†2\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\leq\frac{G^{2}}{2T}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}italic_Ï• ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So, the surrogate loss converges as ğ’ªâ¢(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T)caligraphic_O ( 1 / italic_T ), as expected by a loss with upper curvature.

Now, instead letâ€™s assume that the function fğ‘“fitalic_f is Lğ¿Litalic_L-self-bounded. Using inequalities between harmonic and arithmetic means, we have

1âˆ‘t=1T1â€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–2â‰¤1T2â¢âˆ‘t=1Tâ€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–2=1T2â¢âˆ‘t=1Tâ€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–4â€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–2â‰¤1T2â¢âˆ‘t=1T8â¢L2â¢Ï•â¢(ğ’™t)â€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–2â‰¤8â¢L2T2â¢12â¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2,1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡21superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡21superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡4superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡21superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡8superscriptğ¿2italic-Ï•subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡28superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ‘‡212superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†2\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}}\|^{2}}}\leq\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}}\|^{2}=\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}% _{t}}\|^{4}}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}}\|^{2}}\leq\frac{1}{T^{2}}% \sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{8L^{2}\phi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{% \boldsymbol{x}_{t}}\|^{2}}\leq\frac{8L^{2}}{T^{2}}\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_% {1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2},divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where in the last inequality we use (4). This implies

Ï•â¢(ğ’™Â¯T)â‰¤12â¢âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2=12â¢âˆ‘t=1T1â€–ğ’ˆğ’™tâ€–2â¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2â‰¤4â¢L2T2â¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–4.italic-Ï•subscriptÂ¯ğ’™ğ‘‡12superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†212superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†24superscriptğ¿2superscriptğ‘‡2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†4\phi(\bar{\boldsymbol{x}}_{T})\leq\frac{1}{2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}}\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}=\frac{1}{2\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{% 1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{x}_{t}}\|^{2}}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\frac{4L^{2}}{T^{2}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{4}~{}.italic_Ï• ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - Similarly, it is equally easy to obtain rates for HÃ¶lder-smooth functions.

We can also assume that fğ‘“fitalic_f is sğ‘ sitalic_s-sharp and GğºGitalic_G-Lipschitz. So, from (3) and the fact that Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• has s2superscriptğ‘ 2s^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT quadratic growth from TheoremÂ 1, then by LemmaÂ 1 we have

s2G2â¢â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2â‰¤s2â¢Î·tâ¢â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2â‰¤Î·tâ¢(Ï•â¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’Ï•â¢(ğ’™â‹†))â‰¤12â¢â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’12â¢â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2.superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptğº2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡italic-Ï•subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡italic-Ï•superscriptğ’™â‹†12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†212superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†2\frac{s^{2}}{G^{2}}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq s^{2}% \eta_{t}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\leq\eta_{t}(\phi(% \boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\leq\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{% x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}~{}.divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Using the fact that s2G2â‰¤1superscriptğ‘ 2superscriptğº21\frac{s^{2}}{G^{2}}\leq 1divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ 1, this immediately gives a linear convergence rate.

5 Generalizing the Polyak Stepsize: More Surrogates and Stochastic Setting

We have shown how the Polyak stepsize is just GD on a particular function with stepsizes adapted to the local curvature of the function. In this section, we show that we can construct an entire family of surrogate losses with similar guarantees, while also preparing ourselves for the stochastic setting.

Instead of the functionÂ (2), we consider more generally the surrogate

Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)=12â¢h2â¢(ğ’™),ğœ“ğ’™12superscriptâ„2ğ’™\psi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x}),italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ,

where h:â„dâ†’â„â‰¥â¢0:â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq}0italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 is convex. As a special case we can recoverÂ (2) with hâ¢(ğ’™)=fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ‹†â„ğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™superscriptğ‘“â‹†h(\boldsymbol{x})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-f^{\star}italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, however, in general we do not need to know fâ‹†superscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For example we can take h=(fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’a)+â„subscriptğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘h=(f(\boldsymbol{x})-a)_{+}italic_h = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_a ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any ağ‘aitalic_a. Intuitively, the role of hâ„hitalic_h is to transform fğ‘“fitalic_f into a positive function. We show that Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ generally has an approximate local-star-upper curvature, where the approximation stems from hâ„hitalic_h potentially being strictly positive in ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 4 (Approximate local-star-upper curvature).

We will say that a function fğ‘“fitalic_f with minimizer ğ±â‹†superscriptğ±â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ-approximate Î»ğ²subscriptğœ†ğ²\lambda_{\boldsymbol{y}}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-star-upper-curvature around ğ²ğ²\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y if there exists Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ such that

fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’š,ğ’™â‹†âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¥12â¢Î»ğ’šâ¢â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–22âˆ’Ïµ,âˆ€ğ’ˆğ’šâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’š).formulae-sequenceğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ‘“ğ’šsubscriptğ’ˆğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†ğ’š12subscriptğœ†ğ’šsubscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š22italic-Ïµfor-allsubscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ‘“ğ’šf(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-f(\boldsymbol{y})-\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol% {y}},\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle\geq\frac{1}{2\lambda_{% \boldsymbol{y}}}\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}_{2}-\epsilon,\ \forall% \boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_y âŸ© â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ , âˆ€ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) .

Since we do not make explicit assumptions hâ„hitalic_h with respect to fğ‘“fitalic_f, we can only hope to achieve convergence to the minimum of hâ„hitalic_h or Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ. So, from here onward we denote ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as as minizer of Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ.

Lemma 2.

Let h:â„dâ†’â„â‰¥0:â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptâ„absent0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be convex. Define Ïˆ=12â¢h2ğœ“12superscriptâ„2\psi=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}italic_Ïˆ = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ is (2â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ±)â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ±â‹†)âˆ’Ïˆâ¢(ğ±â‹†))2ğœ“ğ±ğœ“superscriptğ±â‹†ğœ“superscriptğ±â‹†(2\sqrt{\psi(\boldsymbol{x})\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})}-\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^% {\star}))( 2 square-root start_ARG italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG - italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) )-approximate â€–ğ â€–normğ \|\boldsymbol{g}\|âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥-LSUC for any ğ âˆˆâˆ‚hâ¢(ğ±)ğ â„ğ±\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ).

Proof.

Given that the function Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)ğœ“ğ’™\psi(\boldsymbol{x})italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) might not be differentiable, we have to be careful in the calculation of its subgradients. We have

Ïˆâ¢(ğ’š)ğœ“ğ’š\displaystyle\psi(\boldsymbol{y})italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_y ) =12â¢h2â¢(ğ’š)â‰¥12â¢h2â¢(ğ’™)+hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢[hâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’hâ¢(ğ’™)]absent12superscriptâ„2ğ’š12superscriptâ„2ğ’™â„ğ’™delimited-[]â„ğ’šâ„ğ’™\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{y})\geq\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol% {x})+h(\boldsymbol{x})[h(\boldsymbol{y})-h(\boldsymbol{x})]= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_y ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) + italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) [ italic_h ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ]
â‰¥12â¢h2â¢(ğ’™)+hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™âŸ©=Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)+âŸ¨hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢ğ’ˆ,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™âŸ©,absent12superscriptâ„2ğ’™â„ğ’™ğ’ˆğ’šğ’™ğœ“ğ’™â„ğ’™ğ’ˆğ’šğ’™\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x})+h(\boldsymbol{x})\langle% \boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle=\psi(\boldsymbol{x})+% \langle h(\boldsymbol{x})\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\rangle,â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) + italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x âŸ© = italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) + âŸ¨ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x âŸ© ,

where ğ’ˆâˆˆâˆ‚hâ¢(ğ’™)ğ’ˆâ„ğ’™\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) and the first inequality is due to the fact that 12â¢(â‹…)212superscriptâ‹…2\frac{1}{2}(\cdot)^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( â‹… ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a convex function. Hence, we see that ğ’ˆ~:=hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢ğ’ˆassign~ğ’ˆâ„ğ’™ğ’ˆ\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}:=h(\boldsymbol{x})\boldsymbol{g}over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG := italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) bold_italic_g is a subgradient of Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ in ğ’™ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x. Hence, for any ğ’–âˆˆâ„dğ’–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_u âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆ~,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’–âŸ©+12â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–2â¢â€–ğ’ˆ~â€–22ğœ“ğ’™~ğ’ˆğ’™ğ’–12superscriptnormğ’ˆ2subscriptsuperscriptnorm~ğ’ˆ22\displaystyle\psi(\boldsymbol{x})-\langle\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}},\boldsymbol{x}% -\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+\frac{1}{2\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g% }}\|^{2}_{2}italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) - âŸ¨ over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u âŸ© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ over~ start_ARG bold_italic_g end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =12h2(ğ’™))âˆ’h(ğ’™)âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’–âŸ©+12h(ğ’™)2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x}))-h(\boldsymbol{x})\langle% \boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+\frac{1}{2}h(\boldsymbol{x% })^{2}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u âŸ© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢(hâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’–âŸ©)absentâ„ğ’™â„ğ’™ğ’ˆğ’™ğ’–\displaystyle=h(\boldsymbol{x})\left(h(\boldsymbol{x})-\langle\boldsymbol{g},% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle\right)= italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u âŸ© )
=hâ¢(ğ’™)â¢(hâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’hâ¢(ğ’–)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’–âŸ©+hâ¢(ğ’–))absentâ„ğ’™â„ğ’™â„ğ’–ğ’ˆğ’™ğ’–â„ğ’–\displaystyle=h(\boldsymbol{x})\left(h(\boldsymbol{x})-h(\boldsymbol{u})-% \langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{u}\rangle+h(\boldsymbol{u})\right)= italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_u âŸ© + italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) )
â‰¤hâ¢(ğ’™)â‹…hâ¢(ğ’–)=2â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)â¢Ïˆâ¢(ğ’–),absentâ‹…â„ğ’™â„ğ’–2ğœ“ğ’™ğœ“ğ’–\displaystyle\leq h(\boldsymbol{x})\cdot h(\boldsymbol{u})=2\sqrt{\psi(% \boldsymbol{x})\psi(\boldsymbol{u})},â‰¤ italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) â‹… italic_h ( bold_italic_u ) = 2 square-root start_ARG italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ) italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_u ) end_ARG ,

where the inequality is due to the convexity of hâ„hitalic_h and the fact that hâ¢(ğ’™)â‰¥0â„ğ’™0h(\boldsymbol{x})\geq 0italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) â‰¥ 0. Setting ğ’–âˆˆargminğ’™Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™)ğ’–subscriptargminğ’™ğœ“ğ’™\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \psi(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_u âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x ), we have the stated bound. âˆ

With approximate local curvature, a generalization of LemmaÂ 1 is immediate.

Lemma 3.

Assume Ïˆ:â„dâ†’â„:ğœ“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\psi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_Ïˆ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R to be Ïµtsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon_{t}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-approximately Î»tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda_{t}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-star-upper-curve around ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, for any Î·t>0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡0\eta_{t}>0italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, any ğ tâˆˆâˆ‚Ïˆâ¢(ğ±t)subscriptğ ğ‘¡ğœ“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial\psi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ğ±t+1=ğ±tâˆ’Î·tâ¢ğ tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡1subscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptğ ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\eta_{t}\boldsymbol{g}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have

Î·tâ¢(Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))â‰¤â€–ğ’™â‹†âˆ’ğ’™tâ€–222âˆ’â€–ğ’™â‹†âˆ’ğ’™t+1â€–222+Î·t2â¢(Î·tâˆ’1Î»t)â¢â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2+Î·tâ¢Ïµt.subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡ğœ“subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğœ“superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡222subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1222subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\eta_{t}(\psi(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\leq\frac{\|% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\|^{2}_{2}}{2}-\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}% ^{\star}-\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}\|^{2}_{2}}{2}+\frac{\eta_{t}}{2}\left(\eta_{t}-% \frac{1}{\lambda_{t}}\right)\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}+\eta_{t}\epsilon_{t}~{}.italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The last two lemmas tells us that the properties of the surrogate functions breaks if Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰ 0ğœ“superscriptğ’™â‹†0\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\neq 0italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰  0. Hence, we will not be able to prove convergence results, but only that, for example, the suboptimality gap will converge up to a floor that depends on Ïˆâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)ğœ“superscriptğ’™â‹†\psi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_Ïˆ ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). However, in SectionÂ 6 we will show that this is not an artifact of the proof. Indeed, we can construct simple one-dimensional functions where the generalized Polyak stepsize does not converge.

5.1 Stochastic Approximation Setting

Consider now the case that we are minimizing Fâ¢(ğ’™):=ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]assignğ¹ğ’™subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒF(\boldsymbol{x}):=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[f(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) := blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ], where f:â„dÃ—ğ’®â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ’®â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— caligraphic_S â†’ blackboard_R, that covers both the stochastic approximation and finite-sum settings. We do not know the distribution Dğ·Ditalic_D, but we assume that we can sample ğƒğƒ\boldsymbol{\xi}bold_italic_Î¾ i.i.d. from Dğ·Ditalic_D.

In this setting, we argue that the Polyak stepsize makes sense only in restricted settings. In fact, the interpretation of the Polyak stepsize as minimizing a surrogate function implies that in the stochastic setting we will minimize the function ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[12â¢h2â¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]12superscriptâ„2ğ’™ğƒ\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ], where the function hâ¢(â‹…,ğƒ)â„â‹…ğƒh(\cdot,\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( â‹… , bold_italic_Î¾ ) depends on the particular variant of the stochastic Polyak stepsize. It is clear that in general argminğ’™ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]subscriptargminğ’™subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒ\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}% [f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ] can be completely different from argminğ’™ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[12â¢h2â¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]subscriptargminğ’™subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]12superscriptâ„2ğ’™ğƒ\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}% [\frac{1}{2}h^{2}(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ].

Here, starting from ALI-GÂ (Berrada etÂ al., 2020) and SPSmaxÂ (Loizou etÂ al., 2021) that use the idea of limiting the stepsizes, we propose a generalized Polyak stepsize algorithm. The proof is in AppendixÂ C.

Theorem 3.

Let h:â„dÃ—ğ’®â†’â„â‰¥0:â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ’®subscriptâ„absent0h:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— caligraphic_S â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be convex. Denote by Hâ¢(ğ±)=ğ”¼ğ›âˆ¼Dâ¢[hâ¢(ğ±,ğ›)]ğ»ğ±subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ›ğ·delimited-[]â„ğ±ğ›H(\boldsymbol{x})=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[h(\boldsymbol{x},% \boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ]. Choosing the function hâ„hitalic_h, the above theorem covers and extends a number of results in previous papers, for example:

  • â€¢

    SPSmax (Loizou etÂ al., 2021): hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)=fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)âˆ’infğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)â„ğ’™ğƒğ‘“ğ’™ğƒsubscriptinfimumğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-\inf_{% \boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ), so Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)=ğ”¼â¢[fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†,ğƒ)âˆ’infğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğƒsubscriptinfimumğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒH(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=\mathbb{E}[f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}% )-\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¾ ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ].

  • â€¢

    SPSmaxâ„“subscriptsuperscriptabsentâ„“{}^{\ell}_{\max}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Orvieto etÂ al., 2022): hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)=fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)âˆ’qâ¢(ğƒ)â„ğ’™ğƒğ‘“ğ’™ğƒğ‘ğƒh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-q(% \boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) - italic_q ( bold_italic_Î¾ ), where qâ¢(ğ’™i)ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘–q(\boldsymbol{x}_{i})italic_q ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a lower bound to infğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)subscriptinfimumğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒ\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ).
