  • â€¢

    SPS+ (Garrigos etÂ al., 2023): hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)=(fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†,ğƒ))+â„ğ’™ğƒsubscriptğ‘“ğ’™ğƒğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğƒh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=(f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-f(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}))_{+}italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)=0ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†0H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=0italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 so we can also safely set Î³=âˆğ›¾\gamma=\inftyitalic_Î³ = âˆ. Moreover, Hâ¢(ğ’™)â‰¥Fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’Fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)ğ»ğ’™ğ¹ğ’™ğ¹superscriptğ’™â‹†H(\boldsymbol{x})\geq F(\boldsymbol{x})-F(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) â‰¥ italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_F ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), hence any bound on Hâ¢(ğ’™)ğ»ğ’™H(\boldsymbol{x})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) translates to a bound on the suboptimality gap.

Remark 1.

If hâ¢(ğ±â‹†,ğ›t)=0â„superscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ›ğ‘¡0h(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})=0italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 for all tğ‘¡titalic_t, then â€–ğ±t+1âˆ’ğ±â‹†â€–â‰¤â€–ğ±tâˆ’ğ±â‹†â€–normsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡1superscriptğ±â‹†normsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡superscriptğ±â‹†\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥. Hence, in this case we only need to consider all the properties of hâ„hitalic_h in the bounded domain {ğ±âˆˆâ„d:â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ±â‹†â€–â‰¤â€–ğ±1âˆ’ğ±â‹†â€–}conditional-setğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘normğ±superscriptğ±â‹†normsubscriptğ±1superscriptğ±â‹†\{\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|% \leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|\}{ bold_italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ }. This is well-known via the subgradient projector perspective, as ğ±tsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is guaranteed to approach the set â‹‚ğ›{ğ±:hâ¢(ğ±,Î¾)=0}subscriptğ›conditional-setğ±â„ğ±ğœ‰0\bigcap_{\boldsymbol{\xi}}\{\boldsymbol{x}:h(\boldsymbol{x},\xi)=0\}â‹‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { bold_italic_x : italic_h ( bold_italic_x , italic_Î¾ ) = 0 } at each iteration if it is non-empty. This property was observed in Gower etÂ al. (2025) for SPS+Â (Garrigos etÂ al., 2023), but here it holds more generally. For example, hâ¢(ğ±,ğ›)=(fâ¢(ğ±,ğ›)âˆ’a)+â„ğ±ğ›subscriptğ‘“ğ±ğ›ğ‘h(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=(f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})-a)_{+}italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) - italic_a ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where aâ‰¥supÎ¾minğ±â¡fâ¢(ğ±,ğ›)ğ‘subscriptsupremumğœ‰subscriptğ±ğ‘“ğ±ğ›a\geq\sup_{\xi}\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_a â‰¥ roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¾ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ), would also have no neighbourhood of convergence and satisfies the assumption of the theorem.

Remark 2.

The above theorem also applies to the case where some of the fâ¢(â‹…,Î¾)ğ‘“â‹…ğœ‰f(\cdot,\xi)italic_f ( â‹… , italic_Î¾ ) are non-convex functions, while still guaranteeing the convergence to the global optimum of Fğ¹Fitalic_F. For example, consider Fâ¢(x)=0.5â¢f1â¢(x)+0.5â¢f2â¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥0.5subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥0.5subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥F(x)=0.5f_{1}(x)+0.5f_{2}(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) = 0.5 italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + 0.5 italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), where f1=âˆ’|x|subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥f_{1}=-|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - | italic_x | (non-convex) and f2=2â¢|x|subscriptğ‘“22ğ‘¥f_{2}=2|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2 | italic_x |. We have that Fâ¢(x)=12â¢|x|ğ¹ğ‘¥12ğ‘¥F(x)=\frac{1}{2}|x|italic_F ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG | italic_x | so ğ±â‹†=0superscriptğ±â‹†0\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}=0bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0. Now, choose h1â¢(x)=maxâ¡(f1â¢(x)âˆ’f1â¢(xâ‹†),0)=0subscriptâ„1ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“1superscriptğ‘¥â‹†00h_{1}(x)=\max(f_{1}(x)-f_{1}(x^{\star}),0)=0italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , 0 ) = 0 and h2â¢(x)=maxâ¡(f2â¢(x)âˆ’f2â¢(xâ‹†),0)=2â¢|x|subscriptâ„2ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“2superscriptğ‘¥â‹†02ğ‘¥h_{2}(x)=\max(f_{2}(x)-f_{2}(x^{\star}),0)=2|x|italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = roman_max ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , 0 ) = 2 | italic_x |. Hence, the hypotheses of the theorem are verified. Moreover, Hâ¢(x)=0.5â¢h1â¢(x)+0.5â¢h2â¢(x)â‰¥Fâ¢(x)ğ»ğ‘¥0.5subscriptâ„1ğ‘¥0.5subscriptâ„2ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥H(x)=0.5h_{1}(x)+0.5h_{2}(x)\geq F(x)italic_H ( italic_x ) = 0.5 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + 0.5 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) â‰¥ italic_F ( italic_x ) and Hâ¢(xâ‹†)=0ğ»superscriptğ‘¥â‹†0H(x^{\star})=0italic_H ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, so the theorem implies a convergence rate for the minimization of Fâ¢(x)âˆ’Fâ¢(xâ‹†)ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥â‹†F(x)-F(x^{\star})italic_F ( italic_x ) - italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) by using SPS+.

Remark 3.

In the proof of TheoremÂ 3, if one stops before taking expectations, one obtains a regret guarantee on a sequence of arbitrary losses hâ¢(ğ±,ğ›t)â„ğ±subscriptğ›ğ‘¡h(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi}_{t})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Such regret scales as the sum of the loss in ğ±â‹†superscriptğ±â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is exactly the Lâ‹†superscriptğ¿â‹†L^{\star}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bound that we mentioned in SectionÂ 2. Indeed, this kind of updates and guarantees were already obtained in the online learning literature for the special case of linear predictors by the Passive-Aggressive family of algorithmsÂ (Crammer etÂ al., 2006).

Besides covering a number of previous algorithmic variants, we also extend the previous known guarantees. In particular, Loizou etÂ al. (2021) did not prove a guarantee for the non-smooth setting. So, our result proves for the first time that SPSmaxÂ  is adaptive to the entire range of upper curvature of the function, from Lipschitz to smooth functions. In AppendixÂ D we also show additional results. Moreover, the second result in the smooth case is new, and it allows to recover the SGD guarantee on Hğ»Hitalic_H when Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is sufficiently small. For example, we include a precise statement for SPS+ when fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒf(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) is Lğ¿Litalic_L-self-bounded, that recovers the guarantee in Gower etÂ al. (2025, Corollary 2.3).

6 Neighbourhood of Convergence and Instability of Polyak Stepsize

In SectionÂ 5 we demonstrate that a generalized version of the Polyak stepsize and existing variants can be viewed as GD on a function with approximate local curvature, with convergence to a neighbourhood of the optimal solution. This neighbourhood of convergence appears in our analysis just like in all existing variants, therefore suggesting it is unavoidable if

Hâ¢(ğ’™)=ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]>0â¢Â for allÂ â¢ğ’™.ğ»ğ’™subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]â„ğ’™ğƒ0Â for allÂ ğ’™\displaystyle H(\boldsymbol{x})=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[h(% \boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]>0\,\mbox{ for all }\boldsymbol{x}~{}.italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ] > 0 for all bold_italic_x . (5)

In this section, we demonstrate that this neighbourhood of convergence is not an artifact of the analysis and indeed cannot be avoided in general. We also show that the positivity conditionÂ (5) can fundamentally change the dynamics of AlgorithmÂ 1, even in the deterministic setting, thus posing a challenge that is not just associated with interpolation.

ConditionÂ (5) occurs with SPSÂ (Loizou etÂ al., 2021) without interpolation, or in the deterministic setting when the optimal value is underestimated, hâ¢(ğ’™)=fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’câ„ğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘h(\boldsymbol{x})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-citalic_h ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_c where fâ‹†>csuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘f^{\star}>citalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_c. Convergence under this condition was first studied in the deterministic case in Polyakâ€™s original paperÂ (Polyak, 1969), where it is shown that if infxhâ¢(x)=hâ‹†>0subscriptinfimumğ‘¥â„ğ‘¥superscriptâ„â‹†0\inf_{x}h(x)=h^{\star}>0roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_x ) = italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 then limtâ†’âˆmin1â‰¤sâ‰¤tâ¡hâ¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’hâ‹†â‰¤hâ‹†subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscript1ğ‘ ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptâ„â‹†superscriptâ„â‹†\lim_{t\to\infty}\min_{1\leq s\leq t}h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})-h^{\star}\leq h^{\star}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 â‰¤ italic_s â‰¤ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. That is, the best iterate eventually enters a neighbourhood of the minima where the size of the neighbourhood is dependent on how much hâ‹†superscriptâ„â‹†h^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is underestimated by 0. In the stochastic case, convergence of the average iterate to a neighbourhood when understimating the minimum was also studied byÂ Orvieto etÂ al. (2022) under SPSmaxâ„“subscriptsuperscriptabsentâ„“{}^{\ell}_{\max}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, we demonstrate the consequence of conditionÂ (5) is far greater than existing results suggest, with instability of fixed points, potential cycles, lower bounds in the sub-optimality gap, and lack of convergence regardless of initialization.

Deterministic Setting. We first demonstrate that in the deterministic setting, for different classes of hâ„hitalic_h, if hâ‹†=minxâ¡hâ¢(ğ’™)>0superscriptâ„â‹†subscriptğ‘¥â„ğ’™0h^{\star}=\min_{x}h(\boldsymbol{x})>0italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) > 0, then the fixed points of

ğ’™t+1=Tâ¢(ğ’™t):={ğ’™tâˆ’hâ¢(ğ’™t)â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2â¢ğ’ˆt,Â ifÂ â¢ğ’ˆtâˆˆâˆ‚hâ¢(ğ’™t),â€‰0âˆ‰âˆ‚hâ¢(ğ’™t),ğ’™t,Â otherwisesubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡assigncasessubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2subscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡formulae-sequenceÂ ifÂ subscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡â€‰0â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡Â otherwise\displaystyle\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}=T(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}):=\begin{cases}% \boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\frac{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}% \boldsymbol{g}_{t},&\mbox{ if }\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\in\partial h(\boldsymbol{x}_% {t}),\,0\notin\partial h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t}),\\ \boldsymbol{x}_{t},&\mbox{ otherwise}\end{cases}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := { start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL if bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 0 âˆ‰ âˆ‚ italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL otherwise end_CELL end_ROW (6)

are unstable. Intuitively, this can be explained via our surrogate function view: In fact, denoting the local curvature constant of the surrogate 12â¢(hâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’hâ‹†)212superscriptâ„ğ’™superscriptâ„â‹†2\frac{1}{2}(h(\boldsymbol{x})-h^{\star})^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT around ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{x}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as Î»tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda_{t}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we see that the stepsize Î·tsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t}italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in update (6) can be equivalently written as

Î·t=(hâ¢(ğ’™t)hâ¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’hâ‹†)â¢1Î»t.subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptâ„â‹†1subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\displaystyle\eta_{t}=\left(\frac{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{h(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})% -h^{\star}}\right)\frac{1}{\lambda_{t}}.italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( divide start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_h ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG . (7)

If hâ„hitalic_h is Lipschitz or self-bounded then Î·tâ†’+âˆâ†’subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta_{t}\to+\inftyitalic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ + âˆ as ğ’™tâ†’ğ’™â‹†â†’subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}_{t}\to\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, if hâ„hitalic_h possesses curvature, then ğ’™t+1subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may move further away from ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT within a neighborhood of ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, in PropositionÂ 1 we show that for all self-bounded functions with a quadratic growth condition, the fixed point of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T in Â (6) is unstable. A similar result can also be shown if hâ„hitalic_h is Lğ¿Litalic_L-Lipschitz and has a sharp mininum (see PropositionÂ 6 in the Appendix).

Proposition 1 (Unstable fixed point).

Suppose hâ„hitalic_h is convex, strictly positive, Lğ¿Litalic_L-self-bounded, and satisfies the quadratic growth condition hâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’hâ‹†â‰¥Î¼2â¢â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ±â‹†â€–2â„ğ±superscriptâ„â‹†ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ±superscriptğ±â‹†2h(\boldsymbol{x})-h^{\star}\geq\frac{\mu}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star}\|^{2}italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ±â‹†=argâ¡minğ±â¡hâ¢(ğ±)superscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ±â„ğ±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}=\arg\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}h(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x ) is the only fixed point of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T, defined inÂ (6). Then, for any point ğ±âˆˆS={ğ²:ğ²â‰ ğ±â‹†,hâ¢(ğ²)âˆ’hâ‹†<hâ‹†â¢Î¼8â¢Lâˆ’Î¼}ğ±ğ‘†conditional-setğ²formulae-sequenceğ²superscriptğ±â‹†â„ğ²superscriptâ„â‹†superscriptâ„â‹†ğœ‡8ğ¿ğœ‡\boldsymbol{x}\in S=\{\boldsymbol{y}:\boldsymbol{y}\neq\boldsymbol{x}^{\star},% h(\boldsymbol{y})-h^{\star}<h^{\star}\frac{\mu}{8L-\mu}\}bold_italic_x âˆˆ italic_S = { bold_italic_y : bold_italic_y â‰  bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 8 italic_L - italic_Î¼ end_ARG } we have

â€–Tâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–>â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–.normğ‘‡ğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†normğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†\|T(\boldsymbol{x})-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|>\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star}\|~{}.âˆ¥ italic_T ( bold_italic_x ) - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ > âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Note that this reinforces the need to clip the stepsize as proposed in ALI-G and SPSmax. However, clipping will not remove this behaviour unless the maximum value is taken to be small enough. In PropositionÂ 5 we show there is always a subregion where the stepsize is bounded, and this subregion can be made arbitrarily large within the unstable region; therefore, if the clipped value is too large instability is unavoidable.

The importance of h>0â„0h>0italic_h > 0 in updateÂ (6) has also been studied in Bauschke etÂ al. (2018), where they demonstrate with examples that Tğ‘‡Titalic_T can fail to be quasi-firmly non-expansive if hâ‹†>0superscriptâ„â‹†0h^{\star}>0italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0. Propositions Â 1, and Â 6 provide extra insight on this phenomenon as they automatically prove Tğ‘‡Titalic_T cannot be quasi-firmly non-expansive and therefore we have the following remark.

Remark 4.

If h>0â„0h>0italic_h > 0, and either of the following conditions hold:

  • â€¢

    hâ„hitalic_h is convex, self-bounded, and satisfies the quadratic growth condition,

  • â€¢

    hâ„hitalic_h is convex, Lipschitz, and has a sharp minimum,

then Tğ‘‡Titalic_T from (6) is not quasi-firmly non-expansive.

While LemmasÂ 1Â andÂ 6 establish that minima can be unstable, this property may not fully describe the dynamics of updateÂ (6). In fact, instability can admit convergence in the average iterate or last iterate if the local critical neighborhood is skipped. So, in PropositionÂ 2 we provide an example of a function hâ„hitalic_h, which satisfies the assumptions of PropositionÂ 1, where the iterates cycle and never reach the minimum in best iterate or on average.

Proposition 2 (Cycling and failure to converge).

There exists a strictly positive smooth and strongly convex function hâ„hitalic_h, and an initial point ğ±1subscriptğ±1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that iterates from updateÂ (6) cycle and satisfy the inequality hâ¢(1tâ¢âˆ‘i=1tğ±i)âˆ’hâ‹†â‰¥Î´>0â„1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptâ„â‹†ğ›¿0h(\frac{1}{t}\sum_{i=1}^{t}\boldsymbol{x}_{i})-h^{\star}\geq\delta>0italic_h ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_t end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Î´ > 0 for all tğ‘¡titalic_t.

Note that since the cycle in PropositionÂ 2 consists of a finite number of points, clipping will not necessarily remove this behaviour (e.g. if the clipped value is taken to be larger than any of the seen stepsizes). In PropositionÂ 2, a specific initialization was chosen to construct a cycle that would not converge. However, in PropositionÂ 3 we show that for 1-d quadratics the lack of convergence is true for all initializations and values of hâ‹†superscriptâ„â‹†h^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT up to a set of measure zero.

Proposition 3 (The set of good initializations can have measure zero).

Let h:â„â†’â„:â„â†’â„â„h:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : blackboard_R â†’ blackboard_R, defined as hâ¢(x)=x22+aâ„ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥22ğ‘h(x)=\frac{x^{2}}{2}+aitalic_h ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_a for a>0ğ‘0a>0italic_a > 0, where xt+1=xtâˆ’hâ¢(xt)â€–âˆ‡hâ¢(xt)â€–2â¢âˆ‡hâ¢(xt)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptnormâˆ‡â„subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2âˆ‡â„subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t+1}=x_{t}-\frac{h(x_{t})}{\|\nabla h(x_{t})\|^{2}}\nabla h(x_{t})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‡ italic_h ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and ğ±1subscriptğ±1\boldsymbol{x}_{1}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is randomly initialized. Then, Pâ¢{limtâ†’âˆxt=xâ‹†}=0ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥â‹†0P\{\lim_{t\to\infty}x_{t}=x^{\star}\}=0italic_P { roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } = 0. In other words, the set of initializations that can converge to the optimal solution has measure zero.

Proof.

Note hâ„hitalic_h is 1-smooth and 1-strongly convex and therefore satisfies the conditions of Proposition 1 with Î¼=L=1ğœ‡ğ¿1\mu=L=1italic_Î¼ = italic_L = 1 and an unstable unique fixed point. Let Tğ‘‡Titalic_T be such that xt+1=Tâ¢(xt)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t+1}=T(x_{t})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_T ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Tâ¢(x)=xâ¢(12âˆ’ax2)ğ‘‡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥12ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥2T(x)=x\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{a}{x^{2}}\right)italic_T ( italic_x ) = italic_x ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_a end_ARG start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) if xâ‰ 0ğ‘¥0x\neq 0italic_x â‰  0 and 00 otherwise. With inverse Tâˆ’1â¢(S)={xÂ±x2+2â¢a:xâˆˆS}superscriptğ‘‡1ğ‘†conditional-setplus-or-minusğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥22ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘†T^{-1}(S)=\{x\pm\sqrt{x^{2}+2a}:x\in S\}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S ) = { italic_x Â± square-root start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_a end_ARG : italic_x âˆˆ italic_S }. Therefore, Tâˆ’kâ¢({xâ‹†})superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥â‹†T^{-k}(\{x^{\star}\})italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ) has at most 2ksuperscript2ğ‘˜2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT points which has measure zero for all kğ‘˜kitalic_k. By LemmaÂ 6 in AppendixÂ E, the result follows. âˆ

Remark 5.

Note that, by LemmaÂ 6, PropositionÂ 3 can be extended much more generally if Tğ‘‡Titalic_T from (6) is shown to satisfy the Lusin (Nâˆ’1superscriptğ‘1N^{-1}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) propertyÂ (Hencl and Koskela, 2014, Definition 4.12).

In the stochastic case with SPS, conditionÂ (5) is due to lack of interpolation, and Orvieto etÂ al. (2022) show that it can change the expected fixed point. In contrast, in the deterministic setting we have shown lack of convergence despite the fixed point being ğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore the issue here stems from the instability of the method due to the under estimation of hâ‹†superscriptâ„â‹†h^{\star}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and not the bias of the expected update.

Stochastic case. In the stochastic setting, the positivity conditionÂ (5) can occur despite minğ’™â¡hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)=0subscriptğ’™â„ğ’™ğƒ0\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}h(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=0roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = 0, such as in SPSÂ (hâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)=fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’minğ’™â¡fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)â„ğ’™ğƒğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒh(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})=f(\boldsymbol{x})-\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(% \boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})italic_h ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) = italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ )) without interpolation. Orvieto etÂ al. (2022) demonstrate that without interpolation SPSÂ can fail to converge in a 1-d quadratic and has an expected fixed point different than minğ’™â¡Fâ¢(ğ’™)=minğ’™â¡ğ”¼ğƒâˆ¼Dâ¢[fâ¢(ğ’™,ğƒ)]subscriptğ’™ğ¹ğ’™subscriptğ’™subscriptğ”¼similar-toğƒğ·delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ’™ğƒ\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}F(\boldsymbol{x})=\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}\mathbb{E}_{% \boldsymbol{\xi}\sim D}[f(\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{\xi})]roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( bold_italic_x ) = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_Î¾ ) ]. Similarly to the deterministic setting, we can show that SPS can have a random walk between a finite number of points.

Proposition 4 (Failure to converge).

There exist f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f2subscriptğ‘“2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT quadratic 1-d functions and a starting point x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that SPS on Fâ¢(x)=0.5â¢(f1â¢(x)+f2â¢(x))ğ¹ğ‘¥0.5subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥F(x)=0.5(f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x))italic_F ( italic_x ) = 0.5 ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ) satisfies

ğ”¼â¢[Fâ¢(xt)]âˆ’minxâ¡Fâ¢(x)â‰¥2/3,âˆ€t.ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥23for-allğ‘¡\mathbb{E}[F(x_{t})]-\min_{x}\ F(x)\geq 2/3,\ \forall t~{}.blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_x ) â‰¥ 2 / 3 , âˆ€ italic_t .
Proof.

Let f1=x2+2â¢x+5subscriptğ‘“1superscriptğ‘¥22ğ‘¥5f_{1}=x^{2}+2x+5italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_x + 5 and f2â¢(x)=2â¢x2âˆ’4â¢x+10subscriptğ‘“2ğ‘¥2superscriptğ‘¥24ğ‘¥10f_{2}(x)=2x^{2}-4x+10italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = 2 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 italic_x + 10. Letâ€™s start from x1=1subscriptğ‘¥11x_{1}=1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 where Fâ¢(x1)=8ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥18F(x_{1})=8italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 8. If we draw f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, x2=âˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥21x_{2}=-1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 1, while if we draw f2subscriptğ‘“2f_{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then x2=1subscriptğ‘¥21x_{2}=1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 because f2â€²â¢(1)=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘“2â€²10f_{2}^{\prime}(1)=0italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) = 0. Hence, ğ”¼â¢[Fâ¢(x2)]=0.5â¢f1â¢(1)+f2â¢(1)2+0.5â¢f1â¢(âˆ’1)+f2â¢(âˆ’1)2=9ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥20.5subscriptğ‘“11subscriptğ‘“2120.5subscriptğ‘“11subscriptğ‘“2129\mathbb{E}[F(x_{2})]=0.5\frac{f_{1}(1)+f_{2}(1)}{2}+0.5\frac{f_{1}(-1)+f_{2}(-% 1)}{2}=9blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = 0.5 divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 0.5 divide start_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - 1 ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( - 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 9. Iterating, we have that x3subscriptğ‘¥3x_{3}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has equal probability to be equal to 1 and -1. Hence, again we have ğ”¼â¢[Fâ¢(x3)]=9ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥39\mathbb{E}[F(x_{3})]=9blackboard_E [ italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] = 9. So, we have that this holds for any tğ‘¡titalic_t. Moreover, we have that minxâ¡Fâ¢(x)=44/6subscriptğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥446\min_{x}F(x)=44/6roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_x ) = 44 / 6. âˆ

7 Discussion and Limitations

We have shown that the design, properties, and failure of the (variants) of the Polyak stepsize can be easily derived through the lens of the minimization of a surrogate objective function. This framework also provides a new and natural explanation on the adaptivity of the stepsize via the local curvature of the surrogate. We believe this framework has the promise to design new variants, by simply designing surrogate functions with the required properties. Furthermore, with our perspective we have provided new insight on the challenge of controlling neighbourhoods of convergence that often appear in variants of the Polyak stepsize. We demonstrate that this neighbourhood is not avoidable and a fundamental issue beyond interpolation causing instability.

The limitations of our framework include the assumption of convex hâ„hitalic_h in the generalized surrogate that must be assumed apriori. It is unclear if this framework can be extended to the more general case of noncovex surrogate functions. The class of such surrogates that admit fast rates and tight neighbourhoods of convergence remains an open question that we leave to future work.

Acknowledgments

We acknowledge the use of Gemini 2.5 in developing the proof of PropositionÂ 2. We also thank Mehdi Inane Ahmed for helpful discussions.

Appendix A Proofs for the Surrogate Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï•

Theorem 1 (Curvature of the Polyak surrogate).

Let fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) be convex and define ğ±â‹†âˆˆargminğ±fâ¢(ğ±)superscriptğ±â‹†subscriptargminğ±ğ‘“ğ±\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). Define Ï•â¢(ğ±)=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ±)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ±â‹†))2italic-Ï•ğ±12superscriptğ‘“ğ±ğ‘“superscriptğ±â‹†2\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^% {2}italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, we have

  • â€¢

    Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š2\|\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-LSUC around any ğ’šğ’š\boldsymbol{y}bold_italic_y for any ğ’ˆğ’šâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’š)subscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ‘“ğ’š\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ).

  • â€¢

    If fğ‘“fitalic_f is sğ‘ sitalic_s-sharp, then Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• has s2superscriptğ‘ 2s^{2}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-quadratic growth.

  • â€¢

    If fğ‘“fitalic_f has Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼-quadratic growth and Lğ¿Litalic_L-self bounded, then Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• satisfies a local quadratic growth:

    Ï•â¢(ğ’™)â‰¥12â¢Î¼â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â¢Lâ¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2,âˆ€ğ’ˆâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™).formulae-sequenceitalic-Ï•ğ’™12ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’ˆ22ğ¿superscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2for-allğ’ˆğ‘“ğ’™\phi(\boldsymbol{x})\geq\frac{1}{2}\frac{\mu\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}{2L}\|% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2},\ \forall\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f% (\boldsymbol{x})~{}.italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , âˆ€ bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) .
Proof.
Ï•italic-Ï•\displaystyle\phiitalic_Ï• (ğ’š)âˆ’Ï•â¢(ğ’™â‹†)âˆ’âŸ¨âˆ‡Ï•â¢(ğ’š),ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©+12â¢â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–2â¢â€–âˆ‡Ï•â¢(ğ’š)â€–22ğ’šitalic-Ï•superscriptğ’™â‹†âˆ‡italic-Ï•ğ’šğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š2subscriptsuperscriptnormâˆ‡italic-Ï•ğ’š22\displaystyle(\boldsymbol{y})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-\langle\nabla\phi(% \boldsymbol{y}),\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle+\frac{1}{2\|% \boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}}\|\nabla\phi(\boldsymbol{y})\|^{2}_{2}( bold_italic_y ) - italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - âŸ¨ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_y ) , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_y ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))2âˆ’(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))â¢âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’š,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©+12â¢â€–ğ’ˆğ’šâ€–2â¢â€–âˆ‡Ï•â¢(ğ’š)â€–2absent12superscriptğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ’š2superscriptnormâˆ‡italic-Ï•ğ’š2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^{2}-(f(% \boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y% }},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle+\frac{1}{2\|\boldsymbol{g}_{% \boldsymbol{y}}\|^{2}}\|\nabla\phi(\boldsymbol{y})\|^{2}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ âˆ‡ italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_y ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))2âˆ’(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))â¢âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’š,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©+(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))22absent12superscriptğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†22\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^{2}-(f(% \boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y% }},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle+\frac{(f(\boldsymbol{y})-f(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))^{2}}{2}= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© + divide start_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG
=(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))â¢(fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆğ’š,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©)absentğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptğ’ˆğ’šğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle=(f(\boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\left(f(\boldsymbol% {y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})-\langle\boldsymbol{g}_{\boldsymbol{y}},% \boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle\right)= ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ( italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© )
â‰¤0,absent0\displaystyle\leq 0,â‰¤ 0 ,

where the inequality is due to the convexity of fğ‘“fitalic_f and the fact that fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¥0ğ‘“ğ’šğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†0f(\boldsymbol{y})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\geq 0italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¥ 0.

For the second property, we have

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¥Î±â¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–â‡’Ï•â¢(ğ’™)âˆ’Ï•â¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¥Î±22â¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2.ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ›¼normğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†â‡’italic-Ï•ğ’™italic-Ï•superscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ›¼22superscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\geq\alpha\|\boldsymbol{x}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|\Rightarrow\phi(\boldsymbol{x})-\phi(\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star})\geq\frac{\alpha^{2}}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_Î± âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‡’ italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

For the third property we have

Ï•â¢(ğ’™)=12â¢(fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))2â‰¥â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â¢Lâ¢(fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†))â‰¥12â¢Î¼â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â¢Lâ¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2.italic-Ï•ğ’™12superscriptğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptnormğ’ˆ22ğ¿ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†12ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’ˆ22ğ¿superscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†2\displaystyle\phi(\boldsymbol{x})=\frac{1}{2}(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{% x}^{\star}))^{2}\geq\frac{\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}{2L}(f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}))\geq\frac{1}{2}\frac{\mu\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}}{2L}\|% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}.italic_Ï• ( bold_italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG ( italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

âˆ

Appendix B Relationship between Star Upper Curvature and Upper Quadratic Growth

For a function fğ‘“fitalic_f, denote by ğ’³â‹†:={ğ’™:fâ¢(ğ’™)=minğ’™â¡fâ¢(ğ’™)}assignsuperscriptğ’³â‹†conditional-setğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™\mathcal{X}^{\star}:=\{\boldsymbol{x}:f(\boldsymbol{x})=\min_{\boldsymbol{x}}% \ f(\boldsymbol{x})\}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { bold_italic_x : italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) }. In Guille-Escuret etÂ al. [2021], they define the following function class.

Definition 5.

A function fğ‘“fitalic_f is Lğ¿Litalic_L-quadratically upper bounded (denoted Lğ¿Litalic_L-QG+) if for all ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ‹†â‰¤L2â¢minğ’™â‹†âˆˆğ’³â‹†â¡â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–22.ğ‘“ğ’™superscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ¿2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’³â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†22f(\boldsymbol{x})-f^{\star}\leq\frac{L}{2}\min_{\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in% \mathcal{X}^{\star}}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}_{2}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_L end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

We now show that convex Lğ¿Litalic_L-QG+ are globally Lğ¿Litalic_L-star upper curved, while the other direction is true for the local version of the two definitions.

Theorem 5.

Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be a convex Lğ¿Litalic_L-QG+ functions, then fğ‘“fitalic_f is globally Lğ¿Litalic_L-star upper curved. On the other hand, let fğ‘“fitalic_f be Lğ±subscriptğ¿ğ±L_{\boldsymbol{x}}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-LSUC, then for all ğ±ğ±\boldsymbol{x}bold_italic_x we have

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ‹†â‰¤Lğ’™2â¢minğ’™â‹†âˆˆğ’³â‹†â¡â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–22.ğ‘“ğ’™superscriptğ‘“â‹†subscriptğ¿ğ’™2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’³â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†22f(\boldsymbol{x})-f^{\star}\leq\frac{L_{\boldsymbol{x}}}{2}\min_{\boldsymbol{x% }^{\star}\in\mathcal{X}^{\star}}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}_% {2}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Proof.

Assume that fğ‘“fitalic_f is Lğ¿Litalic_L-QG+. Then, we have

fâ¢(ğ’š)+âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâŸ©â‰¤fâ¢(ğ’™)â‰¤fâ‹†+L2â¢minğ’™â€²âˆˆğ’³â‹†â¡â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â€²â€–22,ğ‘“ğ’šğ’ˆğ’™ğ’šğ‘“ğ’™superscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ¿2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™â€²superscriptğ’³â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â€²22f(\boldsymbol{y})+\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle% \leq f(\boldsymbol{x})\leq f^{\star}+\frac{L}{2}\min_{\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}% \in\mathcal{X}^{\star}}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}\|^{2}_{2},italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) + âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_y âŸ© â‰¤ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) â‰¤ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_L end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where the first inequality is due to convexity and ğ’ˆâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’š)ğ’ˆğ‘“ğ’š\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{y})bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_y ). Now, set ğ’™=ğ’™â‹†+1Lâ¢ğ’ˆğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†1ğ¿ğ’ˆ\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}+\frac{1}{L}\boldsymbol{g}bold_italic_x = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG bold_italic_g for any ğ’™â‹†âˆˆğ’³â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’³â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathcal{X}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, to have

fâ¢(ğ’š)âˆ’fâ‹†ğ‘“ğ’šsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†\displaystyle f(\boldsymbol{y})-f^{\star}italic_f ( bold_italic_y ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™â‹†+1Lâ¢ğ’ˆâˆ’ğ’šâŸ©+L2â¢minğ’™â€²âˆˆğ’³â‹†â¡â€–ğ’™â‹†+1Lâ¢ğ’ˆâˆ’ğ’™â€²â€–22â‰¤âˆ’âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™â‹†+1Lâ¢ğ’ˆâˆ’ğ’šâŸ©+â€–ğ’ˆâ€–222â¢Labsentğ’ˆsuperscriptğ’™â‹†1ğ¿ğ’ˆğ’šğ¿2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™â€²superscriptğ’³â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ’™â‹†1ğ¿ğ’ˆsuperscriptğ’™â€²22ğ’ˆsuperscriptğ’™â‹†1ğ¿ğ’ˆğ’šsubscriptsuperscriptnormğ’ˆ222ğ¿\displaystyle\leq-\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}+\frac{1}{L}% \boldsymbol{g}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle+\frac{L}{2}\min_{\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}% \in\mathcal{X}^{\star}}\left\|\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}+\frac{1}{L}\boldsymbol{g}% -\boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}_{2}\leq-\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol% {x}^{\star}+\frac{1}{L}\boldsymbol{g}-\boldsymbol{y}\rangle+\frac{\|% \boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}_{2}}{2L}â‰¤ - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG bold_italic_g - bold_italic_y âŸ© + divide start_ARG italic_L end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG bold_italic_g - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ - âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L end_ARG bold_italic_g - bold_italic_y âŸ© + divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG
=âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’šâˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©âˆ’12â¢Lâ¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22.absentğ’ˆğ’šsuperscriptğ’™â‹†12ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’ˆ22\displaystyle=\langle\boldsymbol{g},\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}% \rangle-\frac{1}{2L}\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}_{2}~{}.= âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_y - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Now, assume that fğ‘“fitalic_f is Î»ğ’™subscriptğœ†ğ’™\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-LSUC and set ğ’ˆâˆˆâˆ‚fâ¢(ğ’™)ğ’ˆğ‘“ğ’™\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_g âˆˆ âˆ‚ italic_f ( bold_italic_x ). For any ğ’™â‹†âˆˆargminğ’™fâ¢(ğ’™)superscriptğ’™â‹†subscriptargminğ’™ğ‘“ğ’™\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathop{\mathrm{argmin}}_{\boldsymbol{x}}\ f(% \boldsymbol{x})bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_italic_x ), using Cauchy-Schwarzâ€™s inequality, we have

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¤âŸ¨ğ’ˆ,ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†âŸ©âˆ’12â¢Î»ğ’™â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â‰¤â€–ğ’ˆâ€–2â¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’12â¢Î»ğ’™â¢â€–ğ’ˆâ€–22â‰¤Î»ğ’™2â¢â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–22.ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘“superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ’ˆğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†12subscriptğœ†ğ’™subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’ˆ22subscriptnormğ’ˆ2subscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†212subscriptğœ†ğ’™subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’ˆ22subscriptğœ†ğ’™2subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â‹†22f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\leq\langle\boldsymbol{g},% \boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\rangle-\frac{1}{2\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}% }}\|\boldsymbol{g}\|^{2}_{2}\leq\|\boldsymbol{g}\|_{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|_{2}-\frac{1}{2\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}}\|\boldsymbol{% g}\|^{2}_{2}\leq\frac{\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}}{2}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol% {x}^{\star}\|^{2}_{2}~{}.italic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ âŸ¨ bold_italic_g , bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Given that this holds for all ğ’™â‹†âˆˆğ’³â‹†superscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptğ’³â‹†\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\in\mathcal{X}^{\star}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it implies

fâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ‹†â‰¤Î»ğ’™2â¢minğ’™â€²âˆˆğ’³â‹†â¡â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’™â€²â€–22.âˆğ‘“ğ’™superscriptğ‘“â‹†subscriptğœ†ğ’™2subscriptsuperscriptğ’™â€²superscriptğ’³â‹†subscriptsuperscriptnormğ’™superscriptğ’™â€²22f(\boldsymbol{x})-f^{\star}\leq\frac{\lambda_{\boldsymbol{x}}}{2}\min_{% \boldsymbol{x}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{\star}}\|\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{x}^% {\prime}\|^{2}_{2}~{}.\qeditalic_f ( bold_italic_x ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_italic_x - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . italic_âˆ

Appendix C Proofs for the Stochastic Surrogate Ïˆğœ“\psiitalic_Ïˆ

Theorem 3.

    where a=Î¼2â¢minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)ğ‘ğœ‡212ğ¿ğ›¾a=\frac{\mu}{2}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)italic_a = divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) and b=2â¢Î³âˆ’minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)ğ‘2ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾b=2\gamma-\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)italic_b = 2 italic_Î³ - roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ).

Proof.

For simplicity, denote by htâ¢(ğ’™)=hâ¢(ğ’™,Î¾t)subscriptâ„ğ‘¡ğ’™â„ğ’™subscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x})=h(\boldsymbol{x},\xi_{t})italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_h ( bold_italic_x , italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

From the LemmaÂ 3, we have

âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ¢12â¢ht2â¢(ğ’™t)â‰¤12â¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2+âˆ‘t=1TÎ·t2â¢(Î·tâˆ’1â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2)â¢â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2â¢ht2â¢(ğ’™t)+âˆ‘t=1TÎ·tâ¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†).superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡12subscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡12superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡2subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2subscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}\frac{1}{2}h^{2}_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\leq\frac{1}{2}% \|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\eta_{t}% }{2}\left(\eta_{t}-\frac{1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}}\right)\|\boldsymbol{g}% _{t}\|^{2}h^{2}_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\eta_{t}h_{t}(% \boldsymbol{x}_{t})h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})~{}.âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

For the last term in the r.h.s., we have

Î·tâ¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)=minâ¡(1â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2,Î³htâ¢(ğ’™t))â¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)â‰¤Î³â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†).subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†1superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2ğ›¾subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ›¾subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†\eta_{t}h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})=\min\left(\frac% {1}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}},\frac{\gamma}{h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}\right% )h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\leq\gamma h_{t}(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star})~{}.italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ italic_Î³ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Observe that if htsubscriptâ„ğ‘¡h_{t}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Lğ¿Litalic_L-self bounded then â€–gtâ€–2â‰¤2â¢Lâ¢(htâ¢(ğ’™)âˆ’infğ’™htâ¢(ğ’™))â‰¤2â¢Lâ¢htâ¢(ğ’™)superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡22ğ¿subscriptâ„ğ‘¡ğ’™subscriptinfimumğ’™subscriptâ„ğ‘¡ğ’™2ğ¿subscriptâ„ğ‘¡ğ’™\|g_{t}\|^{2}\leq 2L(h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x})-\inf_{\boldsymbol{x}}h_{t}(% \boldsymbol{x}))\leq 2Lh_{t}(\boldsymbol{x})âˆ¥ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 2 italic_L ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) - roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ) ) â‰¤ 2 italic_L italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x ). Therefore, we have

minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)â‰¤minâ¡(htâ¢(ğ’™t)â€–ğ’ˆtâ€–2,Î³)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)=Î·tâ¢ht2â¢(ğ’™t).12ğ¿ğ›¾subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡2ğ›¾subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptâ„2ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})\leq\min\left(% \frac{h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})}{\|\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\|^{2}},\gamma\right)h_{t% }(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})=\eta_{t}h^{2}_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}_{t})~{}.roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ roman_min ( divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

For the third result, first of all observe that for any a,b>0ğ‘ğ‘0a,b>0italic_a , italic_b > 0 we have

minâ¡(a,b)=1maxâ¡(1/a,1/b)â‰¥11/a+1/b.ğ‘ğ‘11ğ‘1ğ‘11ğ‘1ğ‘\min(a,b)=\frac{1}{\max(1/a,1/b)}\geq\frac{1}{1/a+1/b}~{}.roman_min ( italic_a , italic_b ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_max ( 1 / italic_a , 1 / italic_b ) end_ARG â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 / italic_a + 1 / italic_b end_ARG .

â‰¤â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2Î³â¢T+2â¢Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)+Gâ¢â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–T+Gâ¢2â¢Î³â¢Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†).absentsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ›¾ğ‘‡2ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†ğºnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†ğ‘‡ğº2ğ›¾ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle\leq\frac{\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}}{% \gamma T}+2H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})+\frac{G\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x% }^{\star}\|}{\sqrt{T}}+G\sqrt{2\gamma H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})}~{}.â‰¤ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ italic_T end_ARG + 2 italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_G âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_ARG + italic_G square-root start_ARG 2 italic_Î³ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG .

For the smooth and quadratic growth case, we have

â‰¤â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2+2â¢Î·tâ¢htâ¢(ğ’™t)â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)absentsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†22subscriptğœ‚ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}+2\eta_{t}h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x% }_{t})h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_Î· start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
â‰¤â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2âˆ’â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2+2â¢Î³â¢htâ¢(ğ’™â‹†).absentsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†22ğ›¾subscriptâ„ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle\leq\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}-\|% \boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}+2\gamma h_{t}(\boldsymbol{x}% ^{\star})~{}.â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 italic_Î³ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Taking expectations and using the quadratic growth assumption on Hğ»Hitalic_H, we have

Î¼2â¢minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)â¢ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]ğœ‡212ğ¿ğ›¾ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2\displaystyle\frac{\mu}{2}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\mathbb{E}\left[% \|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)â¢ğ”¼â¢[Hâ¢(ğ’™t)âˆ’Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)]absent12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ»subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle\leq\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\mathbb{E}[H(\boldsymbol{% x}_{t})-H(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})]â‰¤ roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) blackboard_E [ italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ]
â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]âˆ’ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]+(2â¢Î³âˆ’minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³))â¢Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†).absentğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†22ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|% ^{2}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2% }\right]+\left(2\gamma-\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\right)H(% \boldsymbol{x}^{\star})~{}.â‰¤ blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] - blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + ( 2 italic_Î³ - roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) ) italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Hence, we obtain

ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]â‰¤(1âˆ’a)â¢ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™tâˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]+b,ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’™â‹†21ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ‘\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]\leq% (1-a)\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{t}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]+b,blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ ( 1 - italic_a ) blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + italic_b ,

where a=Î¼2â¢minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³)ğ‘ğœ‡212ğ¿ğ›¾a=\frac{\mu}{2}\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)italic_a = divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) and b=(2â¢Î³âˆ’minâ¡(12â¢L,Î³))â¢Hâ¢(ğ’™â‹†)ğ‘2ğ›¾12ğ¿ğ›¾ğ»superscriptğ’™â‹†b=\left(2\gamma-\min\left(\frac{1}{2L},\gamma\right)\right)H(\boldsymbol{x}^{% \star})italic_b = ( 2 italic_Î³ - roman_min ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L end_ARG , italic_Î³ ) ) italic_H ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Note we have 0â‰¤aâ‰¤Î¼/4â¢Lâ‰¤10ğ‘ğœ‡4ğ¿10\leq a\leq\nicefrac{{\mu}}{{4L}}\leq 10 â‰¤ italic_a â‰¤ / start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_L end_ARG â‰¤ 1. From this inequality, it is immediate to obtain

ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™T+1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]â‰¤ğ”¼â¢[â€–ğ’™1âˆ’ğ’™â‹†â€–2]â¢aT+1+bâ¢1âˆ’aT+11âˆ’a.âˆğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘‡1superscriptğ’™â‹†2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™1superscriptğ’™â‹†2superscriptğ‘ğ‘‡1ğ‘1superscriptğ‘ğ‘‡11ğ‘\mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{T+1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]\leq% \mathbb{E}\left[\|\boldsymbol{x}_{1}-\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}\|^{2}\right]a^{T+1% }+b\frac{1-a^{T+1}}{1-a}~{}.\qedblackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] â‰¤ blackboard_E [ âˆ¥ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b divide start_ARG 1 - italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_a end_ARG . italic_âˆ

Appendix D Additional Convergence Result for Generalized Polyak Stepsize

Corollary 1.
